# China has spent decades making inroads in Latin America. Will the ‘Donroe doctrine’ push it out?

By

[![1289025 CNN Expansion Headshots -- Hong Kong, 16 Aug 2022, Simone McCarthy](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/220831104523-simone-mccarthy.jpg?c=16x9&q=h_270,w_480,c_fill/c_thumb,g_face,w_50,h_50)](https://www.cnn.com/profiles/simone-mccarthy)[Simone McCarthy](https://www.cnn.com/profiles/simone-mccarthy)

20 hr ago

PUBLISHED Jan 31, 2026, 12:01 AM ET

![The Chancay megaport, backed by Chinese shipping giant COSCO, was inaugurated in 2024 and shortens shipping times between South America and China.](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/2024-11-06t170252z-269214447-rc23raa3yjci-rtrmadp-3-apec-peru-china-port.JPG?c=16x9&q=w_1479,c_fill)

Link Copied!


Beijing
—


As the dust cleared around [the capture of Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro](https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/23/americas/venezuela-maduro-fort-tiuna-compound-operation-reconstruction-intl-invs) in a surprise military strike earlier this month, US officials left little question that they had another target too: China.


A longtime friend to the government in Caracas, China has for years pumped money into the oil fields and infrastructure of the South American country. Maduro’s ouster is a blow to that partnership that could leave Chinese banks facing billions in unpaid Venezuelan debt.


But viewed from Beijing, the stakes
